case_name: Shri Sadiq Ali and another v. Election Commission of India

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 70 of 1971 filed by special leave against Election Commission's decision dated 11th January 1971.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPEELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 70 of 1971. Appeal by Special Leave from the decision dated the 11 th January 1971 of the Election Commission of India in the matter of an inquiry under paragraph 15 of the Election Symbols  Reservation and Allotment  Order, 1968.

facts.text: Election Commission held that the political party presided over by Shri Jagjivan Ram was the Indian National Congress entitled to symbol Two Bullocks with Yoke on.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 70 of 1971 has been filed by special leave by Shri Sadiq Ali and another against the order of the Election Commission of India  hereinafter referred to as the Commission  under paragraph 15 of the Election Symbols  Reservation Allotment  Order, 1968  hereinafter referred to as the Symbols Order , whereby the Commission held that for the purpose of allotment of symbol in elections the political party presided over by Shri Jagjivan Ram was the Indian National Congress and was entitled to the symbol of Two Bullocks with Yoke on, reserved for the said Congress.

facts.text: Indian National Congress is a recognised National Party under the Symbols Order with exclusive symbol Two Bullocks with Yoke on.

anchor.surface_text: Indian National Congress  hereinafter referred to as the Congress  is a recognised National Party under the Symbols Order. The symbol of the Two Bullocks with Yoke on was exclusively reserved for the Congress for the purpose of elections to the Houses of Parliament and the Legislative Assemblies of the States and Union Territories.

facts.text: Congress is a voluntary association, not statutory body or registered society, with its own constitution and rules.

anchor.surface_text: The Congress is a voluntary association it is neither a statutory body number a registered society under the Societies Registration Act. It has framed its own companystitution and rules.

facts.text: Shri S. Nijalingappa elected President of Congress from 1st January 1968 for two years.

anchor.surface_text: Shri S. Nijalingappa was elected President of the Congress with effect from 1st January, 1968 for a period of two years.

facts.text: Dr. Zakir Hussain, President of India, died in 1969 leading to split in Congress over presidential nominee choice.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Zakir Hussain, President of India, died in 1969. Split then took place in the Congress Party following differences over the choice of Congress numberinee for the office of the President of India.

facts.text: Two groups emerged: Congress J (Jagjivan Ram as President after Subramaniam) and Congress O (Nijalingappa).

anchor.surface_text: One of the groups elected Shri C. Subramaniam as the President of the Congress. Subsequently, Shri Jagjivan Ram was elected President by this group in place of Shri Subramaniam. For sake of companyvenience this group would hereafter be referred to as Congress J. Shri Nijalingappa companytinued to be the President of the party . represented by the other group which would hereafter be referred to as Congress O.

facts.text: On 21st December 1969, Subramaniam wrote to Chief Election Commissioner claiming change in office-bearers of Congress (Congress J list).

anchor.surface_text: On 21st December, 1969, Shri Subramaniam claiming to be the President of the Congress, addressed a letter to the Chief Election Commissioner stating that there had been a change in the office-bearers of the Congress. Enclosed with the letter was the list of office-bearers of Congress J Party and it was stated that they were the office-bearers of the Congress.

facts.text: On 3rd January 1970, communication on behalf of Congress J stated Jagjivan Ram elected President on December 25, 1969 at Bombay plenary.

anchor.surface_text: On 3rd January, 1970, a companymunication was addressed to the Election Commission on behalf of the Congress J that Shri Jagjivan, Ram had been duly eletced as President of the Congress and had taken charge on December 25, 1969, during the plenary session held at Bombay.

facts.text: On 14th January 1970, Congress O replied denying Subramaniam as President, claiming Nijalingappa is President and Congress J members expelled.

anchor.surface_text: On 14th January, 1970, a reply was sent on behalf of Congress O by its General Secretary, Shri Sadiq Ali. In that reply it was stated that Shri Subramaniam who had styled himself as the President of the Congress was, in fact, number its President and that the duly elected President of the Congress was Shri Nijalingappa. It was also stated that the office-bearers mentioned by Shri Subramaniam including Shri Subramaniam himself, were persons expelled from the Congress and had otherwise ceased to be the members of the Congress.

facts.text: Commission notified both groups on 15th January 1970 of dispute under para 15 Symbols Order and opportunity to be heard.

anchor.surface_text: On 15th January, 1970, a companymunication was addressed by the Commission to the Secretary of Congress J as well as that of Congress O stating that, a dispute appears to have arisen as to which of the two groups is. the recognised political party known as the Indian National Congress for the purposes of the Election Symbols  Reservation Allotment  Order, 1968.

facts.text: Congress J claimed term of Nijalingappa expired 31 Dec 1969 due to invalid extension resolution.

anchor.surface_text: The term of the members of the All India Congress Committee, the Pradesh Congress Committees and the Committees subordinate thereto and of the office-bearers thereof was to expire on 31 st December, 1969, under Article 5 of the Old Constitution. On 28th April, 1969, the Working Committee of the Congress passed a resolution at Faridabad for extending the term...

facts.text: Requisition by over 400 AICC members for meeting; Working Committee rejected on 1 Nov 1969.

anchor.surface_text: A requisition, it is stated, signed by more than 400 members of the All India Congress Committee, out of a total of 707, was sent for calling a meeting of the AR India Congress Committee. Shri Nijalingappa then called a meeting of the Congress Working Committee on 1 st November, 1969.

facts.text: Requisitioned AICC meeting held 22-23 Nov 1969 attended by 435/707 members; removed Nijalingappa, appointed Subramaniam President.

anchor.surface_text: The requisitioned meeting of the All India Congress Committee was held at Delhi on 22nd and 23rd November, 1969 and was, according to the statement, attended by 435 members of the All India Congress Committee out of a total of 707. Shri Nijalingappa and his followers did number attend the requisitioned meeting...

facts.text: Plenary session Bombay 28-29 Dec 1969 under Jagjivan Ram; ratified resolutions; 423/707 AICC attended.

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with the, resolution passed in the above requisitioned meeting, a plena session of the Congress was held in Bombay on 28th and 29th December, 1969. Shri Jagjivan Ram was elected President before the said plenary session. An overwhelming majority of delegates are stated to have attended the plenary session held at Bombay under the Presidentship of Shri Jagjivan Ram.

facts.text: Congress J had majority in Lok Sabha (229/294?) and Rajya Sabha, and most state legislatures.

anchor.surface_text: 229 out of 284 Congress Members of Lok Sabha and 106 out of 147 Congress Members of Rajya Sabha declared their allegiance, to the Congress Government led by Shrimati Indira ,Gandhi as Prime Minister and to the Congress led by Shri Jagjivan Ram as President.

facts.text: Congress O counter-statement on 16 Feb 1970 denying jurisdiction, claiming defectors, invalid meetings.

anchor.surface_text: A companynter-statement was submitted on behalf of Congress O by its General Secretary, Shri Sadiq Ali on 16th February, 1970. The various allegations made in the statement submitted on ,of Congress J were companytroverted and it was stated that the Election Commission had numberjurisdiction to hold the enquiry.

facts.text: Commission framed 4 points on 7 March 1970 including jurisdiction and which group is Congress.

anchor.surface_text: The Commission on 7th March, 1970 framed and settled the following four points for discussion Has the Election Commission jurisdiction within the meaning of paragraph 15 of the Election Symbol  Reservation Allotment  Order 1968...

facts.text: Commission held it had jurisdiction under para 15 despite internal party provisions.

anchor.surface_text: In an order companyering 437 pages... the Commission held on the first point that if had jurisdiction to decide the matter. The, companytention that the Working Committee or the President of Congress O were the only authorities to give a binding decision in the dispute was repelled...

facts.text: Commission applied majority test: Congress J had majority in Parliament, legislatures, AICC, delegates.

anchor.surface_text: Applying the test of majority, the Commission observed that Congress J had the majority out of the total number of members returned on Congress tickets to the Houses of Parliament as well as the majority out of the sum total of the members of all the Legislatures...

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld Commission's use of majority/numerical strength test as relevant.

anchor.surface_text: We can companysequently discover numbererror in the approach of the Commission in applying the rule of majority and numerical strength for deter- mining as to which of the two groups, Congress J and Congress O was the Congress party for the purpose of paragraph 15 of Symbols Order.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 2122-2124 of 1970 from Madras High Court judgment dated 15th June 1970.

anchor.surface_text: AND Civil Appeals Nos. 2122 to 2124 of 1970. Appeals from the judgment and order dated the 15th June, 1970 of the Madras High Court in W.As. Nos. 327 and 345 of 1970 and W.P. No. 513 of 1970.

facts.text: Madras High Court upheld para 15 of Symbols Order as valid.

anchor.surface_text: The Madras High Court repelled the companytention advanced on behalf of the appellants that paragraph 15 was ultra vires and invalid in so far as it companyferred power on the Commission to decide the dispute between two groups of a. political party.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeals, upheld Commission's decision that Congress J is the Congress for symbols.

anchor.surface_text: It would follow from what has been discussed earlier in this judgment that the Symbols Order makes detailed provisions... (implied upholding)

facts.text: Symbols introduced due to illiteracy to help voters identify parties.

anchor.surface_text: It is well known that overwhelming majority of the electorate are illiterate. It was realised that in view of the handicap of illiteracy, it might number be possible for the illiterate voters to cast their votes...

issues.text: Has the Election Commission jurisdiction within the meaning of paragraph 15 of the Election Symbol Reservation Allotment Order 1968, to decide whether any one or none of the rival sections or groups of the Indian National Congress, a national party, is the said Indian National Congress?

anchor.surface_text: Has the Election Commission jurisdiction within the meaning of paragraph 15 of the Election Symbol Reservation Allotment Order 1968, to decide whether any one or none of the rival sections or groups of the Indian National Congress, a national party, is the said lndian National Congress ?

issues.text: Has the Election Commission, for the purpose of undertaking the inquiry to come to a decision as aforesaid, been satisfied on information in its possession that there are two rival sections or groups of the said Indian National Congress each claiming to be that Congress?

anchor.surface_text: Has the Election Commission, for the purpose of undertaking the inquiry to come to a decision as aforesaid, been satisfied on information in its possession that there are two rival sections or groups of the said Indian National Congress each. claiming to be that Congress ?

issues.text: What is the nature of an election symbol under the Election Symbols Reservation and Allotment Order, 1968, and whether an election symbol, whether reserved or free, is property?

anchor.surface_text: What is the nature of an election symbol under the Election Symbols Reservation and Allotment Order, 1968, and whether an election symbol, whether reserved or free, is property ?

issues.text: Whether, on the facts and circumstances available to the Election Commission, any of the alleged rival sections of the said Indian National Congress is that Congress for the purposes of the Election Symbols Reservation and Allotment Order 1968 if so, which is that rival section, or, whether on the facts and circumstances referred to above, none of the rival sections of the said Indian National Congress is that Congress?

anchor.surface_text: The term of the members of the All India Congress Committee... was to expire on 31 st December, 1969, under Article 5 of the Old Constitution. On 28th April, 1969, the Working Committee... passed a resolution... for extending the term... The said resolution... was not legal... not submitted... for ratification... Under the new Constitution... required... to be submitted... within 6 months... expired on 28th October, 1969... became void.

arguments.claim: AICC and delegates reflect primary members' views; practical difficulties in ascertaining primaries.

anchor.surface_text: It is not doubt true that the mass of Congress members are its primary members. There were obvious difficulties in ascertaining who were the primary members... The Commission... could obviously not be expected to take referendum... It can... be legitimately considered that the members of AICC and the delegates reflected by and large the views of the primary members.

arguments.claim: Working Committee majority for O not decisive; no veto power; AICC ratifies.
arguments.court_reasoning: Substantial majority of AICC, delegates, legislatures outweigh.

arguments.claim: Decide per Congress constitution provisions, not majority.
arguments.court_reasoning: Removals/expulsions make constitution test ineffective; majority germane.

arguments.claim: Para 13 governs symbol allotment for candidates, not para 15 for groups.

anchor.surface_text: Reference has been made on behalf of the appellants to paragraph 13 of the Symbols Order... Reading of paragraph 13 makes it plain that it deals with the case of individual candidates... Paragraph 13 has nothing to do with the question of resolving a dispute wherein two rival sections or groups... claim to be that party.

arguments.claim: Symbol cannot be split; only one group gets it.
Para 15 not ultra vires; subserves Symbols Order purpose.

anchor.surface_text: The Madras High Court repelled the contention advanced on behalf of the appellants that paragraph 15 was ultra vires... It would follow from what has been discussed... that the Symbols Order makes detailed provisions... Paragraph 15 is intended to effectuate... the main purposes...

arguments.court_reasoning: Essential for effective exercise of Commission's powers under Art 324, Rules 5/10; presumption of fair exercise.

arguments.claim: Art 327 does not prevent Commission directions; subject to Art 324.

anchor.surface_text: There is also no substance in the contention that as power to make provisions in respect to elections has been given to the Parliament by Article 327... The opening words... subject to the provisions of this Constitution... any law... subject to... Article 324.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: directions to the Returning Officers in respect of the allotment of symbols. The  1  1967 1 S.C.R. 643. allotment of symbols by the Returning Officer

arguments.claim: Free Church case analogous: follow tenets, not majority for property.
arguments.court_reasoning: Political party, no change in aims; not property.

arguments.claim: Supporters of J defaulters in subscription.
arguments.court_reasoning: New point not raised before Commission; factual.

holdings.text: The Election Commission has jurisdiction under paragraph 15 of the Symbols Order to decide which rival section or group of a recognised political party is that party.

anchor.surface_text: Art. 324 of the Constitution provides inter alia that the superintendence, direction and control of the preparation of electoral rolls for and. the conduct of all elections to Parliament and Legislative Assemblies of the States and all elections to the offices of President and Vice-President held under the Constitution shall be vested in the Com- mmission

holdings.reasoning_summary: Para 15 expressly empowers Commission to resolve disputes between rival groups claiming to be the party; upheld despite party constitution claims; essential for effective exercise of Art 324 powers.

holdings.text: The Commission was satisfied, based on information in its possession, that there were two rival sections or groups of the Indian National Congress each claiming to be that Congress.

anchor.surface_text: In an order covering 437 pages... the Commission held on the first point that if had jurisdiction to decide the matter. The, contention that the Working Committee or the President of Congress O were the only authorities to give a binding decision in the dispute was repelled...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Communications from both groups showed claims and counter-claims; Commission notified dispute under para 15.

holdings.text: An election symbol under the Symbols Order is not property.

anchor.surface_text: What is the nature of an election symbol under the Election Symbols Reservation and Allotment Order, 1968, and whether an election symbol, whether reserved or free, is property ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Symbols aid illiterate voters; not proprietary right but aid to voting; disputes over symbols not property disputes for civil courts.

holdings.text: Congress J (group led by Shri Jagjivan Ram) is the Indian National Congress entitled to the reserved symbol 'Two Bullocks with Yoke on' for purposes of symbol allotment.

anchor.surface_text: Applying the test of majority, the Commission observed that Congress J had the majority out of the total number of members returned on Congress tickets to the Houses of Parliament as well as the majority out of the sum total of the members of all the Legislatures...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Congress J had substantial majority in Parliament, state legislatures, AICC, and delegates; numerical strength decisive in democratic organisation.

holdings.text: The test of majority and numerical strength is relevant, germane, and valuable for determining which rival group is the recognised political party under para 15.

anchor.surface_text: We can consequently discover no error in the approach of the Commission in applying the rule of majority and numerical strength for deter- mining as to which of the two groups, Congress J and Congress O was the Congress party for the purpose of paragraph 15 of Symbols Order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Democratic setup prioritises numbers; party constitution test ineffective due to mutual expulsions; analogous to para 6 recognition factors; practical over primary members referendum.

holdings.text: The Commission took into account all available facts and circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: Controversy between the parties has ranged on the question whether the Commission has taken into account all the available facts and circumstances of the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Commission examined multiple tests (constitution, aims/objects, majority); figures not disputed; proper approach to memberships post-split.

holdings.text: Persons heard by the Commission during para 15 proceedings do not become parties entitled to be heard in appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Question during the course of hearing of the appeal has also arisen whether the persons who were heard during the course of proceedings under paragraph 15 become parties to those proceedings SO as to be entitled to be heard in appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parties are the rival sections/groups; others heard at discretion but not parties.

holdings.text: The Commission's decision under para 15 is binding on rival groups only for symbol allotment purposes; constitutes direction to Returning Officers under Rule 10; does not decide property disputes.

anchor.surface_text: Question then arisen as to what is the binding nature of the decision given by the Commission under paragraph 15.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limited to election symbols per para 15 text; property for civil courts; binding on ROs via Rules 10(4),(5).

holdings.text: Paragraph 15 of the Symbols Order is not ultra vires or invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The Madras High Court repelled the contention advanced on behalf of the appellants that paragraph 15 was ultra vires and invalid in so far as it conferred power on the Commission to decide the dispute between two groups of a. political party.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Subserves Symbols Order purpose under Art 324, Rules 5/10; essential for effective symbol allotment; presumption of fair exercise by Commission; not barred by Art 327.

holdings.text: A reserved symbol cannot be split between rival groups; only one group gets it.

anchor.surface_text: It would follow from what has been discussed earlier in this judgment that the Symbols Order makes detailed provisions... (implied upholding)

holdings.reasoning_summary: Symbols aid voters, not divisible property; para 15 decides which group is the party.

precedents.citation: General Assembly of Free Church of Scotland and others v. Lord Overtoun and others 1 ... 1 1904 A.C. 515

anchor.surface_text: Reference has been made on behalf of the appellants to a House of Lords decision in the case of General Assembly of Free Church of Scotland and others v. Lord Overtoun and others 1 . The said case related to the denomination of Christians which called itself the Free Church of Scotland and had been founded in 1843. It companysisted of ministers and laity who seceded from the Established Church of Scotland, but who professed to carry with them the doctrine and system of the Established Church, only freeing themselves by secession from what they regarded as interference by the State in matters spiritual. For manly years, efforts had been made to bring about a union between the Free Church and the United Presbyterian Church, also seceders from the Established Church. In 1900 Acts of Assembly were passed by the majority of the Free Church and unanimously by the United Presbyterian Church for union under the name of the United Free. Church and the Free Church property was companyveyed to the new trustees for behoof of the new Church. The United Presbyterian Church was opposed to the Establishment principle, and did number maintain the West- minster Confession of Faith in its entirety. the respondents companytended that the Free Church had full power to change its doctrines so long as the identity was preserved. The appellants, a very small minority of the Free Church, objected to the union maintaining that the Free Church had numberpower to change its original doctrines or to unite with a body which did number companyfess those doctrines. The appellants accordingly companyplained of breach of trust. It was held that the Establishment principle and the Westminster Confession were distinctive tenets of the Free Church and 1 1904 A.C. 515.

precedents.case_name: General Assembly of Free Church of Scotland v. Lord Overtoun
precedents.cited_proposition: In a split of a religious denomination, the minority adhering to the original doctrines holds the property if the majority changes the fundamental tenets
precedents.cited_holding: the Free Church had no power, where property was concerned, to alter the doctrine of the Church; there was no true union as the United Free Church had not preserved its identity with the Free Church; the appellants were entitled to hold the property for the Free Church

precedents.citation: Samyukto Socialist Party v. Election Commission of India Anr. 1 ... 1 1967 1 S.C.R. 643

anchor.surface_text: The case of Samyukto Socialist Party v. Election Commission of India Anr. 1 has also numberbearing on the present case. The cited case related to merger of two political parties into one as a result of which the election symbol of one of the merger parties was allotted to the new party. The parties separated again and the question which arose for determination was whether the symbol can be taken back from the new party and given to the party to which it originally belonged. It is plain that the nature of companytroversy in the said case was entirely different. 1 1967 1 S.C.R. 643.

precedents.case_name: Samyukta Socialist Party v. Election Commission of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Upon separation after merger of political parties, the symbol allotted to the new party cannot be reclaimed by the original party
